facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 447 of 1963 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 447 of1963. Sup.C-I/65 Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 19, 1960 of Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 128 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Sup.C-I/65 Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 19, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 128 of 1960. Gopal Singh, for the appellant.

facts.text: Consolidation proceedings under East Punjab Holdings Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation Act, 1948 started in 1955 in village Bholpur, District Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1955, companysolidation proceedings under East Punjab Holdings  Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmenta- tion  Act, 1948  hereinafter called the Act  were started in the village Bholpur of District Ludhiana.

facts.text: Scheme for consolidation of holdings published on 29th March, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: In accordance with the provisions of the Act, a scheme for companysolidation of holdings was published on 29th March, 1956.

facts.text: Scheme confirmed under s. 20 of the Act on 14th May, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On 14th May, 1956 that scheme was companyfirmed under s. 20 of the Act. The Consolidation Officer accordingly re-allotted parcels of land

facts.text: Consolidation Officer re-allotted parcels of land to the appellant and respondents Nos. 1 and 8 in village Bholpur.

anchor.surface_text: The Consolidation Officer accordingly re-allotted parcels of land to the appellant and respondents Nos. 1 and 8 in the village of Bholpur.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 8 preferred appeals under s. 21(3) of the Act dissatisfied with allotment, dismissed by Settlement Officer.

anchor.surface_text: Being dissatisfied with the allotment, respondents 1 and 8 preferred appeals under s. 21 3  of the Act but these appeals were dismissed by the Settlement Officer.

facts.text: Respondents 1 and 8 preferred further appeals under s. 21(4) to Assistant Director Consolidation of Holdings.

anchor.surface_text: Respondents 1 and 8 thereafter preferred further appeals under s. 21 4  of the Act to the Assistant Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

facts.text: Assistant Director partially allowed appeal of respondent No. 1 by order dated 29th October, 1957, dismissed appeal of respondent No. 8.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Director partially allowed the appeal of respondent No. 1 by his order dated 29th October, 1957 but dismissed the appeal of respondent No. 8.

facts.text: Appellant moved State Government under s. 42 on 10th February, 1958 for revision of Assistant Director's order in appeal of respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On 10th February, 1958, the appellant moved the State Government under s. 42 of the Act for revision of the order passed by the Assistant Director in the appeal of respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Revision petition accepted on 29th August, 1958 by Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

anchor.surface_text: The Revision Petition was ultimately accepted on 29th August, 1958 by the Director, Consolidation of Holdings.

facts.text: Director held original order of Assistant Director on 29th October, 1957 contrary to scheme and based on mistake of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The Director held that the original order made by the Assistant Director on 29th October, 1957 was companytrary to the scheme and was based upon a mistake of fact.

facts.text: Harbhajan Singh filed two copies of application under s. 42.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Harbhajan Singh had filed two companyies of the application under s. 42 of the Act

facts.text: On one copy, Director ordered on 17th February, 1958 to put up with previous papers.

anchor.surface_text: and on one companyy the Director of Consolidation of Holdings passed an order on 17th February, 1958 that the application should be put up with previous papers.

facts.text: On second copy, Director passed order on 3rd April, 1958 that order of Assistant Director need not be amended.

anchor.surface_text: On the second companyy of the application the Director passed an order on 3rd April, 1958 to the following effect - The order of Assistant Director, Consolidation of Holdings, under s. 21 4  need number be amended.

facts.text: Director heard parties and passed order on 29th August, 1958 on first copy, allowing application of Harbhajan Singh and setting aside Assistant Director's order.

anchor.surface_text: On the companyy of the application on which the order of 17th February, 1958 was passed, the Director heard the parties and passed his order on 29th August, 1958 by which he allowed the application of Harbhajan Singh and set aside the order of the Assistant Director.

facts.text: Respondent No. 1 moved Punjab High Court under Art. 226 for quashing Director's order of 29th August, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 thereafter moved the Punjab High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution for quashing the order of the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, made on 29th August, 1958.

facts.text: Punjab High Court allowed the application on 11th January, 1960, holding Director not competent due to previous order of 3rd April, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The application was allowed by the High Court on 11 th January, 1960 on the ground that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, was number companypetent to pass the order dated 29th August, 1958 in view of his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh.

facts.text: Appellant took Letters Patent Appeal, dismissed on 19th April, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took the matter in appeal under Letters Patent but the appeal was dismissed on 19th April, 1960.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Director had no power to review his order of 3rd April, 1958, subsequent order of 29th August, 1958 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the same principle applies to the present case and the Director, Consolidation of Holdings had numberpower to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 rejecting the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

facts.text: No provision in the Act granting express power of review to State Government under s. 42.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberprovision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act.

facts.text: High Court rightly quashed the Director's order of 29th August, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 19, 1960 of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 128 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: S. 42 of the Act states The State Government may at any time for the purpose of satisfying itself as to the legality or propriety of any order passed, scheme prepared or confirmed or repartition made by any officer under this Act call for and examine, the record of any case pending before or disposed of by such officer and may pass such order in reference thereto as it thinks fit Provided that no order, scheme or repartition shall be varied or reversed without giving the parties interested notice to appear and opportunity to be heard except in cases where the State Government is satisfied that the proceedings have been vitiated by unlawful consideration.

concepts.interpretation: Does not grant express power of review to State Government or Director regarding its own orders under s.42.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: me or repartition shall be varied or reversed without giving the parties interested numberice to appear and opportunity to be heard except in cases wh

concepts.interpretation: Administrative authority like Director has no power to review its own order unless expressly provided by statute; applied to invalidate Director's order dated 29.8.1958.

issues.text: whether the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, had power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 dismissing Harbhajan Singhs application, and whether his subsequent order made under s. 42 of the Act dated 29th August, 1958 is legally valid

anchor.surface_text: The question of law presented for determination in the appeal is, whether the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, had power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 dismissing Harbhajan Singhs application, and whether his subsequent

arguments.claim: The original order made by the Assistant Director on 29th October, 1957 was contrary to the scheme and was based upon a mistake of fact.

anchor.surface_text: The Director held that the original order made by the Assistant Director on 29th October, 1957 was contrary to the scheme and was based upon a mistake of fact.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: under this Act call for and examine, the record of any case pending before or disposed of by such officer and may pass such order in reference theret

arguments.court_reasoning: Director lacked power to review or reconsider previous dismissal order under s.42 absent statutory review power

arguments.claim: The Director, Consolidation of Holdings, was not competent to pass the order dated 29th August, 1958 in view of his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The application was allowed by the High Court on 11 th January, 1960 on the ground that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, was not competent to pass the order dated 29th August, 1958 in view of his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he State Government is satisfied that the proceedings have been vitiated by unlawful companysid

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that order was ultra vires and without jurisdiction

arguments.claim: There is no provision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act.

arguments.claim: In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

arguments.claim: no court and no authority has a power of setting aside an order which has been properly made, unless it is given by statute.

anchor.surface_text: In Drew v. Willis 1 , Lord Esher, M. R. pointed out that ,no court  and I would add no authority  has a power of setting aside an order which has been properly made, unless it is given by statute.

arguments.claim: the court, under the statute, has no power to review an order deliberately made after argument and to entertain a fresh argument upon it with a view to ultimately confirming, or reversing it.

anchor.surface_text: In another case Hession v. Jones 2  Bankes, J. pointed out that the court, under the statute, has no power to review an order deliberately made after argument and to entertain a fresh argument upon it with a view to ultimately confirming, or reversing it

arguments.claim: The power to review must also be given by the statute. Prima facie a party who has obtained a decision is entitled to keep it unassailed, unless the Legislature had indicated the mode by which it can be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The same principle was laid down by the Madras High Court in Anantharaju Shetty v. Appu Hegada 3  in which Seshagiri Aiyar, J. observed It is settled law that a case is no, open to appeal unless the statute gives such a right. The power to review must also be given by the statute.

arguments.claim: the order of March 23, 1900, was final and conclusive, and that, so far as the Commissioner was concerned, he had no power to review that order.

anchor.surface_text: The same principle has been affirmed by the Judicial Committee in Baijnath Ram Goenka v. Nand Kumar Singh 1  in which a mahal was sold for arrears of revenue... Their Lordships are clearly of opinion that the order of March 23, 1900, was final and conclusive, and that, so far as the Commissioner was concerned, he had no power to review that order in the way in which he has reviewed it.

arguments.claim: in the absence of any power of review the Collector had no power to reconsider his previous decisions... and the subsequent order... re-opening the matter was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The same principle has been reiterated by this Court recently in Patel Chunibhai Dajibhai etc. v. Narayanrao Khanderao Jambekar and Another  2  . In that case... it was held by this Court that in the absence of any power of review the Collector had no power to reconsider his previous decisions dated October 3, October 4 and October 17, 1958 and the subsequent order of the Collector dated February 17, 1959 re-opening the matter was illegal, ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: the same principle applies to the present case and the Director, Consolidation of Holdings had no power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 rejecting the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the same principle applies to the present case and the Director, Consolidation of Holdings had no power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 rejecting the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

arguments.claim: the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order by the grant of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: There is no provision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberprovision in the Act granting express power of review to the State Government with regard to an order made under s. 42 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory textual analysis shows no explicit grant of review power over own orders under s.42.

holdings.text: In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any such express power, it is manifest that the Director, Consolidation of Holdings, cannot review his previous order of 3rd April, 1958 dismissing the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle that administrative authorities lack inherent review power absent statute, applied to Director's order.

holdings.text: It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order by the grant of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It follows therefore that the order of the Director dated 29th August, 1958 is ultra vires and without jurisdiction and the High Court was right in quashing that order by the grant of a writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Director's order invalid due to lack of review jurisdiction; High Court's writ jurisdiction properly exercised.

holdings.text: We are of the opinion that the same principle applies to the present case and the Director, Consolidation of Holdings had no power to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 rejecting the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion that the same principle applies to the present case and the Director, Consolidation of Holdings had numberpower to review his previous order dated 3rd April, 1958 rejecting the application of Harbhajan Singh under s. 42 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents (Drew v. Willis, Patel Chunibhai etc.) analogized to hold no review power under s.42.

holdings.text: It follows that the subsequent order of the Director, Consolidation of Holdings dated 29th August, 1958 allowing the application of Harbhajan Singh was ultra vires and illegal and was rightly quashed by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that the subsequent order of the Director, Consolidation of Holdings dated 29th August, 1958 allowing the application of Harbhajan Singh was ultra vires and illegal and was rightly quashed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Culminating application of no-review doctrine to invalidate specific order and affirm High Court.
